para.p:
The pressure as a function of temperature an volume,
⁢ p
( T , V )
, or equivalently the volume as a function of temperature and pressure
⁢ V
( T , p )
, is an important physical observable. Recall that its changes are parameterized by the measurables
β p
and
κ T
. Consider an ideal gas at temperature
T
with
N
particles

Explain the physical meaning of the thermal expansion coefficient
β p
and isothermal compressibility
κ T
, and compute them for an ideal gas.

The first items only involved the EOS,
⁢ p
( T , V )

= U

T

of a mono-atomic ideal gas? What is

= γ
/
C p
C V
? Repeat this question for a diatomic ideal gas.

In class we said that for a general substance (and not necessarily an ideal gas) the specific heats
C p
and
C V
are are related by a formula which we will prove in full generality only later:

Math.text: C _ p = C _ V + (V * T * (kappa _ T) ^ 2) / beta _ p
C _ V + (V * T * (kappa _ T) ^ 2) / beta _ p

para.p: For an ideal gas (and one mole of substance) we have the following special case of this formula:

Math.text: C _ p = C _ V + N * k _ B

para.p: Or

C V

κ T
and
β p
and Eq. (). Using Eq. (), give a rough “handwaving” argument for why
≃
C p
C V
for most solids and liquids, but in gasses
C p
is up to 66% larger than
C V
.

para.p:
serves as a kind of spring constant for the material, and
ρ
is the mass per volume. Air is made of diatomic molecules, primarily (78%) diatomic nitrogen
N 2
. Determine the speed of sound of
N 2
gas at
⁢
20 o
C
treating using only the ideal gas constant
R
and the fact that a nitrogen atom consists of 7 protons and 7 neutrons. Compare with the nominal value for the speed of sound in air. You should find favorable agreement.

(Optional) The frequency of the tuning note (
⁢ A 440
) in the orchestra is 440 Hz. Explain qualitatively why it is the adiabatic compressibility
κ S
, and not the isothermal one
κ T
which is relevant for the speed of sound, by comparing the time scales of oscillation with a typical time scale for heat conduction.

K ∘
and standard pressure of 1 bar. Determine the number of moles of air in the cylinders .

r ≡

= 8

You are expected to know the following Taylor series in addition to
sin
( x )
and
cos
( x )
:

Math.text: e ^ x = 1 + x + (1 / 2factorial) * x ^ 2 + O * x ^ 3
(1 + x) ^ alpha = 1 + alpha * x + ((alpha * (alpha - 1)) / 2factorial) * x ^ 2 + ((alpha * (alpha - 1) * (alpha - 2)) / 3factorial) * x ^ 3 + O * x ^ 4
1 + alpha * x + ((alpha * (alpha - 1)) / 2factorial) * x ^ 2 + ((alpha * (alpha - 1) * (alpha - 2)) / 3factorial) * x ^ 3 + O * x ^ 4

para.p:
These get me through life. Here
x
is considered to be a small, dimensionless, number. The
⁢ O
(
x 3
)
etc shows an estimate for the size of the terms that have been dropped. Some Taylor expansions will be needed in the next problem and throughout the course. These are to be found by combining the Taylor series above. The function we will study in detail is wildly important:

It determines the average number of vibrational quanta in a quantum harmonic oscillator at temperature
T
.

subsection.title: Problem 4. Energy of the quantum harmonic oscillator

para.p: Recall from Homework 4 that the mean energy of a single classical harmonic oscillator interacting with the thermal environment is

Now we will compare this classical result to the quantum version of the harmonic oscillator. This builds on Homework 4 and Homework 3 and you should probably look over Problem 3 of Homework 3: question.

Recall that the energy levels of the oscillator are
=
E n
⁢ n ℏ
ω 0
, where we have shifted what we call zero energy to be ground state energy
= n 0

= n
1 , 2 , …

para.p:
Explain why at high temperatures the
⟨ E ⟩
of the quantum oscillator agrees with the classical one by discussing the significance of the graph in (b) in the high temperature limit.

Consider a diatomic ideal gas. Recall that the mean energy of each molecule consists of a classical contribution from translational degrees of freedom
⁢
3 2
k B
T
, plus a classical contribution from the rotational degrees of freedom
⁢
2 2
k B
T
. Now, a quantum mechanical contribution from the vibrations can added. The energy computed in part (a) is the contribution of the vibrational motion, and was computed quantum mechanically. As discussed in class, the total energy for an ideal gas takes the form
and is independent of the volume.
